newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria frees six detainees awaiting trial.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria frees six detainees awaiting trial.

text.p: Nigeria's military government has released six people held in police custody for between six and 12 years without trial, a human rights group which handled their cases said on Monday.
The Constitutional Rights Project (CRP) said the six, whose names were given and who are not prominent persons, were freed last Wednesday in compliance with a Lagos high court order.
The court ruled that their detention without trial for such long periods was illegal and void, it said.

"The freed persons have been in police custody without trial for periods ranging from six to 12 years and for offences such as suspected robbery and murder," said Sonny Onyegbula, head of the CRP's legal department.

He said CRP's legal department, which provides free services to the under-priviledged and victims of human rights abuses, in December secured the release of 37 other persons detained for long periods without trial.
"We are working on a lot of other cases and we are optimistic we will succeed in securing the release of those invloved," he added.
Military-ruled Nigeria has been under fire from the local and international communities for alleged human rights abuses and lack of democracy.
Africa's most populous country slumped into crisis in 1993 when the army annulled an election aimed at restoring democracy.
Some political detainees were released last year but dozens of others opposed to the government still remain in detention.
The military authorities maintain they are not political prisoners.
